What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain
Comments_List:
Knowledge-
Got a brief overview of drug development from the MERK modules 
Was exposed to some interesting ideas and work from great Yale PIs and researchers 
Briefly learned some principles of pharmacology
Skills- 
none. 
Insights-
My classes overlapped nicely so I could apply some of the concepts I was exposed to in one class to another

I learned a great deal about many drugs, but I thought the most valuable part of the class was the amount of organ system physiology I learned as well. It helped to tie in a lot of different concepts and mechanisms into my understanding of the drugs.
Basic knowledge of PK/PD and more insight into specific pharmacology related subjects like oncology/immunology and cardiology in the larger scope of translational science.
The mechanisms of different classes of drugs, pathology of major diseases, and some info on drug regulation, design, and the FDA approval process.
Much greater insight into basic pharmacological principles. Wide based understanding of the field.
The course allowed me to gain a general understanding of pharmacological concepts such as pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and different classes of drugs and their mechanisms of their action.
Basics of pharmacology including drugs developed towards certain diseases.
I developed framework of knowledge on various classes of therapeutics and their mechanisms of action, toxicity, and efficacy.

Molecular targets of different drugs. 
Molecular mechansims of many physiological processes that reinfornce my physiology knowledge.
Think critically about drug targets and drug design.
Approval process for a drug in the United States.
Learned about many novel, developing approaches for drug discovery such as proteasome degradation.
Know how drugs are designed
Drugs, treatments
Learned a WIDE variety of topics, stories, and applications.

I got an introduction into a variety of topics in pharmacology - including the principles, inflammation, cancer, pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics, heart disease, antibiotics, bio markers and imaging, immunity, etc.
Broader knowledge of pharmacology

This course has some good merits but many flaws. There are certainly interesting lectures. Unfortunately that isn't always the case. Some lecturers are not very good at clearly presenting their information. There are many redundancies between the lectures because there is no communication between the different professors and they repeat information. Additionally, the course sequence is lacking. The chemotherapy lecture was at least a month after the targeted therapies for cancer lecture. This doesn't make any sense. There should be a better structure to it. Additionally, the amount of information presented is too much. Some of the test questions ask for very hyperspecific minutia that are not important to the learning of the fundamentals of the subject. I agree that the specific information should be presented to the students, but it shouldn't be the basis of the grades.

There was a lot of information provided in the course; however, due to the numerous instructors involved, it became difficult to succinctly connect all the material. So overall, though I do felt as though I received a lot from some professors, and little from others, I believe the information was too disjointed to yield a lasting impression.

Strengths- 
Some lecturers are incredibly engaging and present fascinating work
The first two lectures were AMAZING and I think need to be expanded as they really delve into the principles of pharmacology which are so important to anyone that wants to do work on the field 
You get exposed to the research of labs at Yale you could potentially do a rotation in
Weaknesses-
Some lecturers were hard to follow and did not even stick to their slides. From the perspective of a student taking preparing for an exam, large presentations with no clear takeaways for the exam cause loss of time studying information the lecturer does not consider necessary- I recommend standardizing an objectives slide or having the TAs communicate with the lecturers and get the gist of the essential knowledge for the exam. 
There was no clear organization between presentations 
I think I learned more about exciting new research than pharmacology principles

This course felt unorganized. I do feel as though I learned a lot, and some of the lectures were fascinating, but it is difficult to understand what is expected of students when each lecture is taught by a new faculty member. Also, many faculty members did not give adequate feedback on exam questions.

I think some professors need some regulations in what they teach us and what they test us on. Some presentations were enormous amounts of information for just a small fraction of it actually on the test.

Strengths were the dynamic lectures, lots of really good Professors who all had great content. Weakness was the lack of class participation and outside group activities to facilitate a better learning experience.
Having so many teachers is a bit overwhelming. Some professors were a lot better lecturers than others, and some of the professors were very mediocre lecturers.
The course could stand to be more structured -- a little scatterbrained in terms of how lectures were structured and what the order of material taught was

Strengths: Lecture material is up to date with current research, for instance cancer immunotherapy.  Lectures cover a broad spectrum of topics. 

Weaknesses: Some professors seemed unprepared while presenting lecture material; lectures were not structured and it was hard to follow the material. As a result, exam preparation required more effort because important concepts were not explained well sometimes.  Grading of exams also seemed unstructured and sometimes absolutely no explanations were given. This lack of feedback was frustrating because I did not know why exactly what I wrote was wrong or inaccurate.   In some instances, after showing my exam to TFs, they were not able to tell me where I made a mistake and my answers looked correct to them, which made me think that grading was not fair.

Strengths: Leaders in the field presenting work with which they are personally engaged.

Weaknesses: No common thread/themes, disjointed due to constant switching of lecturer.
I would add more molecular mechanisms and include more CNS drugs and renal drugs.
The grades on  many exam questions did not have explanations as to why points were taken off.
Some instructors seemed to lack enthusiasm. Feedback given for exams was sparse and not helpful. Expectations for what we should retain from lectures was unclear.

Strengths: The amount of information covered, the different professors for each topic, and the mix of students in the course

Weaknesses: There is no general format for the professors. They teach whatever they want with no structure, knowledge of what other lectures have discussed, or background about the class such as time for each lecture, class dynamic, or type of students. Some professor spent the whole lecture discussing details of drugs that have no application to many majors while others took the time doing a general overview of the subject they were assigned with background, general drug mechanisms, and stories (preferred). Many professors came in and gave a lecture that was only understood or applicable to a small amount of the students. Also many subjects or drugs were talked about in multiple lectures, making it hard to remember which professor wanted which information on the exam. I think each professor should be given background information about the class dynamics (grad school year and majors) and be given a brief structure to follow. Also the tests were very poorly set up. The rooms were always set up last minute and there was not enough room for us each to comfortably take the exam. The teachers should also be given an approximate time their question should take the student.

Strengths: It is nice having a different professor for each topic, because it ensures that the professor is interested in that particular topic and it keeps the class interesting because the professor wants to teach. 

Weaknesses: Some professors have way too many slides and are often rushing toward the end and not covering the later material as well. For our exams, some professors cut off points but did not give comments or mark anything incorrect; consequently it was difficult to see where one had gone wrong.
Professors need to ask exam questions that can be completed within the exam time slot.

I would recommend it with a lot of reservations. I went into it thinking pharmacology would be interesting, and certainly some topics were. However, the structure of the course and the lack of organization on the part of some of the professors made it much less engaging than it could be. Therefore, I would only recommend it to people who are extremely interested in pharmacology.
Honestly, no.
Yes. It is a required course for my program and I did find it to be interesting overall.
Yes!
Yes, if the student had interest in advancement Pharmacology study.
Yes and no -- the course is intellectually stimulating, and very educational, the information is very broad, and doesn't always align with what the title of the course suggests.
Yes. A lot of important topics in biomedicine covered here. Definitely piques interest for those who wish to learn about the interface in basic and translational research.
I would recommend this course to someone looking to get an overview of pharmacological topics, but not necessarily to someone who desires an in-depth look at pharmacological principles.

I definitely would they wanted to improve their physiology knowledge and think critically about potential therapeutic targets commonly encountered in a basic physiology course. Very interesting and challenging.
Yes,the speakers are very professional.
I would not recommend this course

Maybe. This course has the potential to be amazing. If every professor chosen would take the time to design a well thought out lecture with background, important, mechanisms and application of their specific subject, it would be incredible. The chance to take a class with this many subjects and possible connections with speakers is not one to pass up, but its poor design made me disappointed.
Yes, I would recommend the course. It was interesting and covered a wide range of topics.
All of the ideas presented in the course were interesting and useful, but the format was difficult with different professors having different teaching and examination styles.
